fields.body:
The film industry loves a sequel and Crispin Lilly is aiming to refurbish old buildings around the country in a bid to turn the Everyman cinema chain into a nationwide blockbuster.

The chain, which nearly doubled in size last year to reach 16 cinemas, is planning to open up to five a year for the next three years. It has already tied down seven sites in new developments, including in Harrogate and Chelmsford, but wants to boost expansion by acquiring other sites ripe for refurbishment.

“There is something in the walls that comes out that you can’t manufacture,” says Lilly, who joined Everyman as chief executive two years ago, after more than 22 years in the cinema industry working for MGM, Virgin, UGC and Cineworld, thanks to a series of corporate takeovers.

Last year’s expansion was bumped up with the acquisition of four former Odeons – in Muswell Hill and Barnet in north London, Gerrards Cross in Buckinghamshire, and Esher in Surrey – funded by a £20m share placing. The group also put a further £8m in bank debt in its back pocket to support similar projects such as the reopening of an Art Deco cinema in Bristol which had been derelict for 17 years. “If anyone thinks they have got an existing cinema and wants to move on, or an old bingo hall or just a cute space we can fit in, we’re interested,” says Lilly.

The Odeon business, which was sold to the Chinese-backed company AMC last month for £920m, was happy to offload ageing high street sites as it concentrated on opening out of town multiplexes. Potentially AMC will speed up that process and Lilly says: “If they’re up for selling we’re up for buying.” Since reopening the former Odeons under the Everyman brand, box office takings have risen 60% on average. “We completely change the business model and can make these buildings work. There is nothing more satisfying than bringing an old cinema back to life,” says Lilly.

The group began life in 2000 when investors led by the young entrepreneur Daniel Broch rescued the Hampstead Everyman from administration. The venture is backed by Paul Wise, Everyman’s chairman, Leonard Lewis, of the family behind the River Island fashion chain, as well as Adam and Sam Kaye, founders of the Ask pizza chain. Right from the beginning, the group was interested in creating venues that were as much about food and drink as film.

But the idea really took off in 2008, when the team bought the Screen group of cinemas, adding seven more sites including the first venues outside north London. The business floated on the junior Aim market in 2013, raising £8m to support expansion. It now has a market capitalisation of £52m and expects to deliver its first pretax profit this year while building its portfolio outside its north London heartland.

While multiplexes cater for the mainstream cinemagoer, Everyman and similar arthouse chains like Curzon and Picturehouse operate at the upper end of the market. “There is definitely a rise in boutique cinemas – they are tapping into a slightly different audience,” says leisure industry analyst Nigel Parson, at Canaccord Genuity. “Not everyone wants to go to a multiplex.”

Lilly says that offering a gin and tonic or wine in a glass, nice cake and comfy sofas from which to enjoy films helps creates a regular loyal audience. “We are targeting people who want a night out and want something more special and are prepared to pay a little bit more for extra experience,” Lilly says. That includes well-off older folk, but also young professionals and families. “Probably only teenagers are not really interested in us,” says Lilly.

All cinemas are being helped by an overall buoyant market, with admissions up 10% in the UK last year on the back of the Star Wars and Bond blockbusters, but also new digital technology which makes it easier to put on a varied programme of films in one day, rather than being stuck with one showreel. The renaissance in boutique cinemas is also being aided by the changing nature of film distribution, with an ever widening array of options for viewing films – from the likes of Netflix, Amazon Prime to DVDs, Blu-Ray and iTunes.

While big cinema chains vociferously defend the 16-week theatrical release window before movies become available on other media, it offers opportunity to boutiques, that are prepared to run films for shorter periods and are arguably less vulnerable to competition from home viewing services because of the premium experience they offer, according to Lilly.

The boutique groups account for only about 6% of the UK cinema market, but on certain quirky films like Florence Foster Jenkins, the film about an opera-mad New York heiress, starring Meryl Streep, they can take as much as 20% of the box office. Last year Everyman’s No1 film was Spectre, the latest in the Bond franchise, just like every other cinema. But Everyman’s top 10 included the screen version of Alan Bennett’s The Lady in the Van and the Stephen Hawking biopic The Theory of Everything which were both outside the national top 10.

The appeal of the boutique chains has been tarnished by rows over the use of zero-hours contracts and low pay. All the boutique chains have been criticised and Everyman continues to use zero-hours contracts, which do not promise regular hours to staff. Poor pay and conditions grates when punters are paying as much as £18.50 a pop to watch a film.

Lilly says dropping the flexibility of zero-hours agreements “could seriously compromise the efficiency of the business because of the way admissions come and go”. But the group has been experimenting with guaranteed monthly hours at its Birmingham branch and now plans to roll out the scheme to one or two other cinemas in the near future. “We think we could find a middle ground that will work well,” he says.

fields.standfirst: Boutique company buying up empty Odeons and former ‘picture houses’ to give film-goers a G&T on the sofa-style experience
